page.title: 07FARMING AROUND MITCHELDEAN
page.content: Large areas on the hills west of Mitcheldean are forests, with some rough grazing for sheep on land disturbed by old mine workings. There are few farms in this area, and the usable land is mostly pasture. The more intensive farming is confined to the area south and east of Mitcheldean. Here there is a mixed type of farming, with pasture and cereal crops, mostly barley. Cattle are kept, with sheep on the steeper parts of the sandstone ridges. The older farm buildings are of local stone, and in a few places large stone barns survive on the hills, isolated from the farms themselves, and used in the past for winter shelter and food storage.
